conclusion: The rails AB and CD are vertical, connected at the bottom by DE, forming an isosceles right triangle BDE with the right angle at E.
A uniform magnetic field B is directed perpendicularly into the plane of the rails.
The conductor rod MN is horizontal, with a mass m and resistance per unit length r. It slides down the rails and maintains good contact.
The distance between AB and CD is l, and the height difference between MN and BD is also l.
The rod is released from rest and eventually reaches a constant speed v.
The resistance and friction of the rails are negligible, and the acceleration due to gravity is g.
Since the rod moves at a constant speed, the net force acting on it must be zero, implying that the magnetic force balances the gravitational force.
Gravitational force is the weight of the rod mg, acting downward.
Magnetic force is due to the induced current in the rod as it moves downward with velocity v in the magnetic field B.
For the rod to move at constant speed, the magnetic force F_mag must equal the gravitational force mg.
The motional EMF induced in the rod is given by E = B l v.
The total resistance R of the rod is r l.
The current I induced in the rod is I = B l v / r l = B v / r.
The magnetic force on the rod is F_mag = I l B.
Substituting the expression for I, F_mag = (B v / r) l B = B^2 l v / r.
At constant speed, the magnetic force balances the weight: B^2 l v / r = mg.
Rearrange the equation to solve for v: v = mg r / B^2 l.
The units are consistent, confirming the solution is dimensionally correct.
The direction of the magnetic force opposes the motion, consistent with Lenz's law.
The velocity v of the conductor rod MN when it is moving at a constant speed is v = mg r / B^2 l.
